## The Challenge

**Understanding regional economic disparities in Italy**

- Income inequality varies significantly across regions and provinces
- Data is scattered across ISTAT databases
- Static reports fail to show trends over time
- Difficult to compare Liguria with neighboring regions

**Solution needed:**
A tool to visualize and explore income patterns interactively

## Sample Data Analysis
```{r echo=TRUE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, fig.height=4}
# Income data for Liguria provinces (2014-2024)
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)

liguria_provinces <- data.frame(
  Province = rep(c("Genova", "Imperia", "Savona", "La Spezia"), each = 11),
  Year = rep(2014:2024, 4),
  Income = c(
    # Genova
    25200, 25500, 25800, 26300, 26700, 27100, 26500, 27900, 28700, 29400, 30100,
    # Imperia
    22800, 23100, 23400, 23900, 24300, 24700, 24100, 25400, 26100, 26700, 27400,
    # Savona
    23900, 24200, 24500, 25000, 25400, 25800, 25200, 26600, 27400, 28100, 28800,
    # La Spezia
    24100, 24400, 24700, 25200, 25600, 26000, 25400, 26800, 27600, 28300, 29000
  )
)

# Calculate average income per province
avg_income <- aggregate(Income ~ Province, liguria_provinces, mean)
print(avg_income)
```

## Income Growth Visualization
```{r echo=FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, fig.height=4.5, fig.width=8}
library(ggplot2)

ggplot(liguria_provinces, aes(x = Year, y = Income, color = Province, group = Province)) +
  geom_line(size = 1.2) +
  geom_point(size = 2.5) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("#E41A1C", "#377EB8", "#4DAF4A", "#984EA3")) +
  labs(
    title = "Income Per Capita Trends: Liguria Provinces (2014-2024)",
    x = "Year",
    y = "Income per Capita (â‚¬)",
    color = "Province"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 14) +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(face = "bold", hjust = 0.5),
    legend.position = "bottom"
  ) +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma)
```

**Key finding:** Genova consistently leads, but all provinces show growth post-2020

## Why This Matters

**Statistical Insights:**
```{r echo=TRUE}
# Calculate decade growth for each province
growth_2014_2024 <- liguria_provinces %>%
  filter(Year %in% c(2014, 2024)) %>%
  group_by(Province) %>%
  summarize(
    Income_2014 = Income[Year == 2014],
    Income_2024 = Income[Year == 2024],
    Growth_Percent = round(((Income_2024 - Income_2014) / Income_2014) * 100, 1)
  )

print(growth_2014_2024)
```
